natural problem: What is the sum of $101_2$ and $1011_2$? Express your answer in base 2.
natural solution: The rules of addition work in base 2 as well as base 10. Carry any sum greater than 1 to the next place value: \[ \begin{array}{r@{}r@{}r@{}r@{}r} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \phantom{1} \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = bin_of_nat 5"
and h1 : "b = bin_of_nat 11"
shows  "a + b = bin_of_nat 16"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of $101_2$ and $1011_2$? Express your answer in base 2. The final Answer is 10000_2
 ### Proof
 The rules of addition work in base 2 as well as base 10. Carry any sum greater than 1 to the next place value: \[ \begin{array}{r@{}r@{}r@{}r@{}r} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \phantom{1} \\
 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ + & & 1 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \] The sum is $\boxed{10000_2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = bin_of_nat 5"
and h1 : "b = bin_of_nat 11"
shows  "a + b = bin_of_nat 16"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Add 5 and 11 together. The final answer is 16.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat (bin_of BL [True, False, True])"
and h1 : "b = nat (bin_of BL [True, True, False, True])"
shows  "a + b = nat (bin_of BL [True, False, False, False, False])"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of $101_2$ and $1011_2$? Express your answer in base 2. The final Answer is 10000_2
 ### Proof
 The rules of addition work in base 2 as well as base 10. Carry any sum greater than 1 to the next place value: \[ \begin{array}{r@{}r@{}r@{}r@{}r} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \phantom{1} \\
 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ + & & 1 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \] The sum is $\boxed{10000_2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat (bin_of BL [True, False, True])"
and h1 : "b = nat (bin_of BL [True, True, False, True])"
shows  "a + b = nat (bin_of BL [True, False, False, False, False])"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given two binary numbers, where the first binary number is 101 (represented as [True, False, True]) and the second binary number is 1101 (represented as [True, True, False, True]), find the sum of these binary numbers. The final answer is 10000 (represented as [True, False, False, False, False]).

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = of_nat (2^2 + 2^0)"
and h1 : "b = of_nat (2^3 + 2^1 + 2^0)"
shows  "a + b = of_nat (2^4)"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the sum of $101_2$ and $1011_2$? Express your answer in base 2. The final Answer is 10000_2
 ### Proof
 The rules of addition work in base 2 as well as base 10. Carry any sum greater than 1 to the next place value: \[ \begin{array}{r@{}r@{}r@{}r@{}r} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \text{\scriptsize{1}\hspace{0.3mm}} & \phantom{1} \\
 & 1 & 0 & 1 & 1 \\ + & & 1 & 0 & 1 \\ \hline 1 & 0 & 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \] The sum is $\boxed{10000_2}$.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = of_nat (2^2 + 2^0)"
and h1 : "b = of_nat (2^3 + 2^1 + 2^0)"
shows  "a + b = of_nat (2^4)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Calculate the sum of two numbers, where the first number is $2^2 + 2^0$, and the second number is $2^3 + 2^1 + 2^0$. The final answer is $2^4$.

a_4.formal problem:

fixes a b :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = nat (bin_of 0b101)"
and h1 : "b = nat (bin_of 0b1011)"
shows  "a + b = nat (bin_of 0b10000)"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

and h1 : "b = nat (bin_of 0b1011)"
shows  "a + b = nat (bin_of 0b10000)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Add the numbers 5 (which is 101 in binary) and 11 (which is 1011 in binary). The final answer is 16 (which is 10000 in binary).
